utterances: Whatever the motivation, the likely inclusion of tax cuts in the stimulus package may help to win bipartisan support.
Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell predicts that portion of the bill will be met with widespread GOP enthusiasm.
The best way to stimulate the economy obviously is to put money directly into pockets of taxpayers.
Still, McConnell argues that new government spending in the stimulus package must not go for frivolous projects.
He suggests that if states were required to pay back any money they receive from the federal government, they might be more careful about how they spend it.
House Republican Leader John Boehner also worries about the overall size of the stimulus measure at a time when the government is already running big deficits.
This is not a package that's ever going to be paid for by the current generation.
It's going to be paid for by our kids and grandkids.
And so while we want to get the economy moving again, the overall size and how we craft this is going to be very important.
The Obama camp has been talking about a stimulus package in the range of three-quarters of a trillion dollars.
Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid said yesterday it might be even bigger.
I have not received, of course, the exact package from the president-elect and his folks.
But he has indicated that there's at least 20 economists that he's talked with.
And all but one of those believe it should be from 800 billion to one point two or three trillion.
Mr.
Obama stressed that however much money the government spends on the stimulus, the process should be transparent and predictable.
In contrast, the uncertainty he says has hampered some of the government's previous bailout efforts.
Eventually, Mr. Obama says, the government must get control of its deficit spending, just not right away.
Right now, the most important task for us is to stabilize the patient.
The economy is badly damaged.
It is very sick.
And so we have to take whatever steps are required to make sure that it's stabilized.

But we also have to recognize that if we're going to grow this economy over the long term, if we're going to create a better future for our children and our grandchildren, then we can't be fiscally irresponsible about how we do it.
Ultimately, Mr. Obama says, that will require tradeoffs and hard choices.
But for now he's looking to craft a measure that will include something to please everyone.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, Washington.
From NPR News, this is WEEKENDS ON ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
Guy Raz is away.
I'm Linda Wertheimer.

But first, the sounds of nearly two weeks of unrest in that country.
Egyptian protesters filled the streets of Cairo and other cities today, the country's largest demonstrations in years.

And suppressing ideas never succeeds in making them go away.

It needs to be an orderly, peaceful transition to real democracy, not...
There was a big turnout today in central Cairo for what protesters dubbed departure Friday.
If he has perseverance, we have more perseverance.

Time is on our side.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
But, Ed, the game has changed, absolutely, and I think it's because of the speed of the game.
You know, when I played back in 1967, I used to reverse the field.

I said, you know what, if I reverse the field, you know, I can outrun all these guys out there because they were a bunch of white linebackers and safeties and etc., and they did not have the speed that I had.
So if there's one thing that has really changed in the game over the last 30 years that's been the speed of the game because there are more African Americans playing defense.
When I played, there was no black, African-American middle linebacker in the league, and you know, so that today the outside linebackers, you know, they can run as fast as the running backs.
So you have to have that speed, and the game is so fast today, you know, and the guys are big, you know, and they also are much, they're trained.
They're well trained.
We did not lift weights, all right, when we played.
We were out there with just our brute strength and playing the game, so today they are just, they are really prepared to go out there and play.
Bill Rhoden, here's a remarkable point, the hue of the game, the hue of the game has changed a whole lot since 1967.
I mean, Mel alluded to it, but when you looked at the game in 1967, there were a lot of white guys out there.
You don't see that today.

Well, yeah, I mean, that's, when one, generally that's been one of the most remarkable things is just the fact that the league is like 64, 67% black, and I'm sure when Cassidy and his league in the early 60s, they figured that would never happen, but that also leads to what, I think, is the next evolution because of everything that, and by the way, Lem Barney, the greatest cornerback of all times, and when I walked in, Mel introduced me to Miller Farve.
Brother, I said, Miller Farve, this is one of the greatest cats of all time.
I thought, I was like 16, I saw Miller Farve intercept a quick out, and I said I've got to play defensive back.

But anyway, I think that because of everything Mel and Lem said, I think that's where we get the next evolution is at quarterback where brothers now are transforming the game, and although the system is kind of resisting it.
You know, because what happened is every position got bigger, blacker, faster, stronger except quarterback, because that was sort of the American ideal of mister manhood and John Wayne and all that.
And you had to be smart, let them tell it.
Well, yeah, it's one of those business like middle linebacker, guard, quarterback, but if you look...
Center.
Yeah, center.
